content_scrubbed:
In 4 years of undergraduate classes, there were only two semesters I had a class before noon, and three semesters that I had a class on Friday.

Having come to understand early that undergraduate liberal_arts degrees were bullshit, I selected classes exclusively on the basis that:

* Nothing before noon, nothing after 6pm
* Had to count toward major or core requirements.
* Nothing on Friday
* Should be large lecture hall ideally; therefore no attendance would be taken

Worked magnificently.  15 years after graduating, I can say with confidence that I have no regrets.

I also came to understand that if I could schedule classes back-to-back, I was more likely to attend them.  If I had an hour or two between them, the chances I'd skip them increased.

Therefore I only skipped about 60% of my classes, rather than 85 or 90%.

Now I work in a field outside of my major, working alongside and making the same money as people who worked their ass off in their major.

Had I taken college seriously, I probably would have wound up wasting all of the time reading shit I didn't care about, rather than setting aside lots of free time to read shit I did care about, and didn't have to do stupid papers and assignments for.  No self-important professors.  Just kicking back in my apartment or the park and doing what I wanted to do.  While people were jumping through hoops for grades, I was reading the same material for fun, and without all the chaff.  And I still got the undergraduate degree, which is pretty much nothing more than a token into management level positions (graduate degrees are different).

It paid off!
